
---


## I. INDICATORS

---
### 1. Price Deflator

	In economics, the GDP deflator is a measure of the money price of all new, domestically produced, final goods and services in an economy in a year relative to the real value of them. It can be used as a measure of the value of money.

$$
\text{GDP Deflator} = \frac{ \text{Nominal GDP} }
							{ \text{Real GDP} } \times 100
$$

## 2. Consumer Sentiment Index

	The Consumer Sentiment Index (CSI) is a widely followed economic indicator that measures the attitudes and expectations of consumers regarding their financial situation, the overall economy, and their purchasing plans. The index is typically calculated by surveying a representative sample of consumers and asking them about their perceptions of various economic factors.


## 3. Consumer Price Index

	A consumer price index is a price index, the price of a weighted average market basket of consumer goods and services purchased by households. Changes in measured CPI track changes in prices over time. The CPI is calculated by using a representative basket of goods and services.

$$
\text{CPI}_t = \frac{ \text{C}_t  }
					{ \text{C}_0  } \times 100
$$

## 4. Personal Consumption Expenditure

	Personal Consumption Expenditure (PCE) is a measure of the value of goods and services purchased by, or on behalf of, “persons” who reside in the United States. It is a key indicator of consumer spending and inflation.

**Components of PCE**

	PCE includes:

	- Food and beverages
	- Housing
	- Apparel
	- Medical care
	- Transportation
	- Recreation
	- Education and communication
	- Tobacco
	- Other goods and services

**PCE Price Index**

	The PCE Price Index measures the changes in the price of goods and services purchased by consumers for the purpose of consumption, excluding food and energy. It is a chain-type price index that is weighted according to total expenditure per item.

**Core PCE Price Index**

	The Core PCE Price Index is a measure of the price change of goods and services, excluding food and energy. It is a more stable measure of inflation than the headline PCE Price Index, as it is less affected by volatile food and energy prices.

**Importance of PCE**

	PCE is an important indicator of consumer spending and inflation. It is used by the Federal Reserve to gauge the overall health of the economy and to make decisions about monetary policy. It is also used by businesses and investors to make informed decisions about investments and pricing.

**Comparison to CPI**

	PCE is often compared to the Consumer Price Index (CPI), which measures the average change in prices of a basket of goods and services. While both indices measure inflation, PCE is considered a more comprehensive measure of consumer spending, as it includes a wider range of goods and services.


| OIL PRICE             |     |     |
| --------------------- | --- | --- |
| EMPLOYMENT COST INDEX |     |     |
| WAGE GROWTH           |     |     |
| PRODUCE PRICE INDEX   |     |     |
| IMPORT PRICE INDEX    |     |     |
|                       |     |     |

## 5. Wage Growth

  
![Wage Growth vs. Inflation | Overview & Adjustment Formula ...](data:image/jpeg;base64,)

The formula for this is as follows: **real wage in a given year = (nominal wage in that year / CPI in that year) x 100**.

$$
\text{Real Wage}_{i} = \frac{ \text{Nominal Wage}_{i} }
						{ \text{CPI}_{i} }
$$
where, $i$ represents some year.
